facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 238 and 818 of 1962 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 238 and 818 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the awards dated October 21, 1960, and May 17,

facts.text: Appeals against awards dated October 21, 1960 and May 17, 1961 of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Cases Nos. VIII-77 of 1959 and VIII-93 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 238 and 818 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the awards dated October 21, 1960, and May 17, 1961 of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Cases Nos. VIII-77 of 1959 and VIII-93 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant company manufactures aluminium from basic material at factory in J. K. Nagar near Asansol, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant which is engaged in the manufacture of aluminium from basic material has its factory at J. K. Nagar near Asansol in West Bengal.

facts.text: Dispute arose between appellant company and its workmen on bonus for year 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: A dispute having arisen between the appellant and some of its workmen on the question of bonus for the year 1957-58 it was referred to the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, by an order of the Government of West Bengal.

facts.text: Dispute referred to Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal by Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: A dispute having arisen between the appellant and some of its workmen on the question of bonus for the year 1957-58 it was referred to the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, by an order of the Government of West Bengal.

facts.text: Second reference made by Government of West Bengal on May 2, 1959 to same Tribunal including bonus dispute for 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: In another reference made by that Government to the same Tribunal on May 2, 1959 a dispute between the Company and its workmen employed at its factory at J. K. Nagar, Asansol, on the question of bonus for the year 1957-58 was one of the matters referred.

facts.text: In first reference, Tribunal awarded bonus equivalent to three months basic wages inclusive of half month's basic wages already paid voluntarily by company.

anchor.surface_text: In the first reference the Tribunal has awarded in favour of the workmen bonus equivalent to three months basic wages inclusive of the amount equivalent to half a months basic wages that has already been paid by the Company voluntarily.

facts.text: In second reference, parties filed joint petitions agreeing to abide by decision in first reference on bonus issue.

anchor.surface_text: In the second reference the parties filed joint petitions before the Tribunal agreeing to abide by any decision or award whatsoever passed by the Tribunal regarding the bonus issue in the first reference and requesting that similar award be made regarding the issue of bonus in both references.

facts.text: Tribunal in second reference awarded same bonus as in first reference: three months basic wages for 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accordingly passed an order in the second reference that the workmen would get the same bonus as awarded in the first reference. The result of this is that the workmen companyered by the second reference would also be entitled to three months basic wages as bonus for the year 1957-58.

facts.text: Tribunal calculated available surplus as Rs. 4.63 lacs using Full Bench Formula.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the rules embodied in what is known as the Full Bench Formula evolved by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in 1950 and approved by this Court in Associated Cement Companies Ltd., v. Its Workmen 1 for calculation of profit bonus the Tribunal held that the available surplus was Rs. 4.63 lacs.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed Rs. 0.43 lacs as return on reserves used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: In reaching this figure of Rs. 4.63 lacs as the available surplus the Tribunal allowed Rs. 0.43 lacs as return on reserves used as working capital and allowed numberhing under the head rehabilitation charge.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected claim for rehabilitation charge.

anchor.surface_text: In reaching this figure of Rs. 4.63 lacs as the available surplus the Tribunal allowed Rs. 0.43 lacs as return on reserves used as working capital and allowed numberhing under the head rehabilitation charge.

facts.text: Company claimed rehabilitation charge figures varying: Rs. 6,27,234 in statements I and II; Rs. 5,84,534 in III and IV; Rs. 10,25,021 in V and VI.

anchor.surface_text: While however in statements 1 and 11 the rehabilitation charge is shown as Rs. 6,27234.00 it is shown as Rs. 5,84,534.00 in statements III and IV, and in statements V and VI the figure is Rs. 10,25,021.00 How such different figures companyld be arrived at has number been sought to be explained by its only witness, the Manager.

facts.text: Company's assets revalued in 1956 by a Committee including the Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The witness stated that the assets of the Company were revalued in 1956 by a Committee of which he was one of the members. He had added that each of the assets was ascertained with reference to the Companys registers and they were .divided in blocks according to their date of acquisition.

facts.text: Company examined its Manager as witness who put in statements showing available surplus as nil.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant adopted a curious procedure. It examined its Manager and through him put in statements showing its calculations of available surplus. A number of statements were put, in each showing the available surplus as nil.

facts.text: Company claimed reserves used as working capital varying: Rs. 111,74,162 in statements I,III,V; Rs. 199,56,718 in II,IV,VI.

anchor.surface_text: Statements Nos. 1, III and V show the reserves employed in business as Rs. 111,74,162.00, while in statements 11, TV and VI the amount is shown as Rs. 199,56,718.00. The difference is due to the fact that while in statements 1, III and V, the depreciation reserves is shown as Rs. 86 lacs, the companyresponding figure in statements 11, IV and VI is more than double of this, being Rs. 173,82,556.00.

facts.text: Basic wage bill of workmen excluding officers was Rs. 50,000 per month.

anchor.surface_text: It is -not disputed that the wage bill  basic wage  of the workmen, excluding the officers, was Rs. 50,000.

facts.text: Total wage bill including officers Rs. 90,000 per month as per Manager.

anchor.surface_text: This figure of Rs. 90,000/- has been given by the Companys Manager as the total wage of the workmen and the employees, including officers.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 14, 1963 by DAS GUPTA J.

anchor.surface_text: August 14, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by the DAS GUPTA J.-These appeals by special leave are against an award of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on the question of bonus for the year 1957-58 to workmen of the appellant-Company.

facts.text: If three months bonus paid, company still has Rs. 3.91 lacs available surplus including income-tax refund on bonus.

anchor.surface_text: It pointed out that if bonus equivalent to three months basic wage was given to workmen, still the Company will have Rs. 3.91 lacs as the available surplus inclusive of the refund of incometax on account of bonus, which meant an expenditure of only Rs 0.72 lacs on this head by the Company.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal justified in rejecting rehabilitation claim due to lack of proper evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be remembered in this companynection that by a series of decisions of this Court it is number well settled that the burden to prove any prior charge under the head rehabilitation lies on the employer and that unless the employer has by proper evidence established its claim to some amount as rehabilitation charge the claim must be rejected.

facts.text: Allowance of Rs. 0.43 lacs on return on reserves was error in favor of appellant; claim should have been rejected entirely.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal would have been justified in rejecting in toto the Companys claim under this head. The allowance of Rs. 0.43 lacs as prior charge on return on reserves used as working capital was therefore an error in favour of -the appellant.

facts.text: Company voluntarily paid half month's basic wages as bonus already.

anchor.surface_text: In the first reference the Tribunal has awarded in favour of the workmen bonus equivalent to three months basic wages inclusive of the amount equivalent to half a months basic wages that has already been paid by the Company voluntarily.
Appeals by special leave from the awards dated October 21, 1960, and May 17, 1961 of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Cases Nos. VIII-77 of 1959 and VIII-93 of 1959 respectively.
These appeals by special leave are against an award of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on the question of bonus for the year 1957-58 to workmen of the appellant-Company.

Applying the rules embodied in what is known as the Full Bench Formula evolved by the Labour Appellate Tribunal in 1950 and approved by this Court in Associated Cement Companies Ltd., v. Its Workmen 1 for calculation of profit bonus the Tribunal held that the available surplus was Rs. 4.63 lacs.

concepts.interpretation: Tribunal applied the Full Bench Formula to calculate available surplus as Rs. 4.63 lacs after allowing certain prior charges; Supreme Court upheld the application except for minor error in favor of employer.

anchor.surface_text: There is undoubtedly support in standard books on accountancy for the proposition that the excess of the readily realisable, liquid, or current assets of a concern over its current liabilities is the proper measure of the working capital.

concepts.interpretation: Excess of current assets over current liabilities; however, for bonus, focus is on portion of reserves used as working capital, requiring evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal is not concerned with what is paid by the Company to its officers. It is concerned only with the workmens claim of bonus. For deciding therefore what part of the available surplus should be paid to the workmen as bonus the wage bill of the workmen only has to be considered.

concepts.interpretation: Bonus allocation from available surplus based only on workmen's basic wage bill, excluding officers.

concepts.unlisted_description: Tribunal considers only workmen (excluding officers) wage bill for determining bonus quantum.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal was justified in rejecting the claim for rehabilitation charge altogether

anchor.surface_text: On the question of rehabilitation charge Mr. Sastri contended that there was no justification whatsoever for rejecting the claim on this head altogether. It has to be remembered in this connection that by a series of decisions of this Court it is now well settled that the burden to prove any prior charge under the head rehabilitation lies on the employer and that unless the employer has by proper evidence established its claim to some amount as rehabilitation charge the claim must be rejected.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal correctly allowed Rs. 0.43 lacs as return on reserves used as working capital or should have rejected the claim entirely

anchor.surface_text: On the claim of prior charge under the head return on reserves used as working capital, the Tribunal, as already stated, has allowed Rs. 0.43 lacs. What the Company claims under this head is difficult to understand. For, as in the case of rehabilitation charge so also under this head, different figures have been shown in different statements.

issues.text: Whether for determining the quantum of bonus the wage bill should include officers' wages (Rs. 90,000) or only workmen's wages (Rs. 50,000)

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was suggested by Mr. Sastri that in deciding what should be allowed as bonus out of this available surplus the Tribunal should have proceeded on the basis that one months basic wages amount to Rs. 90,000 and not Rs. 50,00 as mentioned by the Tribunal. This figure of Rs. 90,000/- has been given by the Companys Manager as the total wage of the workmen and the employees, including officers.

holdings.text: The burden to prove any prior charge under the head rehabilitation lies on the employer and unless the employer has by proper evidence established its claim to some amount as rehabilitation charge the claim must be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be remembered in this connection that by a series of decisions of this Court it is now well settled that the burden to prove any prior charge under the head rehabilitation lies on the employer and that unless the employer has by proper evidence established its claim to some amount as rehabilitation charge the claim must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Series of decisions of this Court have settled this as law.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was therefore wholly justified in rejecting the claim for rehabilitation.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal -was therefore wholly justified in rejecting the claim for rehabilitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Varying figures not explained by witness, no evidence on multiplier and divisor basis, no cross-examination possible on calculations.

holdings.text: The correctness of the figures as shown in the balance-sheet itself are to be established by proper evidence in Court by those responsible for preparing the balance-sheet or by other competent witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: As has been emphasised in more than one case by this Court, the correctness of the figures as shown in the balance-sheet itself are to be established by proper evidence in Court by those responsible for preparing the balance-sheet or by other competent witnesses. Petlad Turkey Dye Works v. Dyes and Chemical Workers Union 1  and Khandesh Spg. and Weaving Mills Case 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Emphasised in multiple cases including Petlad Turkey Dye Works, Khandesh Spg., Bengal Kagabkal.

holdings.text: The task here is not to ascertain the total working capital of the concern, but to find out what portion of the reserves has been used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: The second difficulty is that the task here is not to ascertain the total working capital of the concern, but to find out what portion of the reserves has been used as working capital. It may often happen that the whole of the working capital is provided from what remained of the subscribed capital after the acquisition of the fixed assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes total working capital from portion funded by reserves; balance-sheet alone insufficient without evidence.

holdings.text: The tribunal would have been justified in rejecting in toto the Companys claim under this head. The allowance of Rs. 0.43 lacs as prior charge on return on reserves used as working capital was therefore an error in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal would have been justified in rejecting in toto the Companys claim under this head. The allowance of Rs. 0.43 lacs as prior charge on return on reserves used as working capital was therefore an error in favour of -the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrary varying figures across statements, no justification or competent evidence provided.

holdings.text: There is no reason therefore for reducing the figure as found by the Tribunal as the available surplus.

anchor.surface_text: There is no reason therefore for reducing the figure as found by the Tribunal as the available surplus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Error in allowing prior charge favored employer, so available surplus figure upheld.

holdings.text: The Industrial Tribunal is not concerned with what is paid by the Company to its officers. It is concerned only with the workmens claim of bonus. For deciding therefore what part of the available surplus should be paid to the workmen as bonus the wage bill of the workmen only has to be considered.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal is not concerned with what is paid by the Company to its officers. It is concerned only with the workmens claim of bonus. For deciding therefore what part of the available surplus should be paid to the workmen as bonus the wage bill of the workmen only has to be considered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's function limited to workmen's bonus claim, excluding officers.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has therefore committed no error in fixing the bonus figures on this basis.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has therefore committed no error in fixing the bonus figures on this basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Basic wage bill of workmen excluding officers is Rs. 50,000 per month.

holdings.text: What we have said in this judgment will not stand in the way of the employer substantiating a claim for rehabilitation charge by proper evidence, in any future dispute on that question.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal is not concerned with what is paid by the Company to its officers. It is concerned only with the workmens claim of bonus.
